tossups.question: At the start of a work by this musical duo, a jaunty leitmotif consisting of a “long, short-short, long, short-short, long-short-short-short, long, short” rhythm begins looping after an opening drum roll and cymbal crash. This duo wrote a “press conference rag” in which the male soloist switches between his voice and a comically high-pitched woman’s voice. A Hungarian woman pleads, “Not (*) guilty!” in a standard by this duo that begins with six women repeating words such as “pop,” “six,” and “squish.” A Christopher Isherwood play inspired a musical by this songwriting duo that begins with the Emcee bidding “willkommen” to the patrons of Berlin’s seedy Kit Kat Klub. For 10 points, name this American songwriting duo who created the musicals Cabaret and Chicago.
tossups.answer: John Kander AND Fred Ebb [accept in either order; accept John Harold Kander in place of “John Kander”]

tossups.question: An observance named for this object was inspired by Juliana of Liège’s vision of a black spot on the moon. A theologian wrote a sentence about this object on a table, then covered it with a velvet cloth, while arguing that this object is “in, with, and under” the “sign.” A tract titled for this object by Tertullian is summarized by the motto “I believe because it is absurd.” Docetism holds that this object was an illusion. First Corinthians Chapter 12 compares the (*) church to this object, which names a feast during which medieval “mystery plays” were often put on after a ritual procession. At the Marburg Colloquy, Martin Luther claimed that this object has “Real Presence.” For 10 points, sacramental bread is transubstantiated into what object, which names the Feast of Corpus Christi?
tossups.answer: body of Christ [or the flesh of Christ; accept answers that include Jesus of Nazareth in place of “Christ”; accept Corpus Christi until “Corpus” is read; accept De Carne Christi; prompt on the body by asking “whose body?”; prompt on Jesus or Christ by asking “which aspect of Christ?”; prompt on the sacramental bread, the communion wafer, the eucharist, or the host until “bread” is read by asking “what object does the bread stand for?”]

tossups.question: A coefficient named for this phenomenon, which approaches negative one in the far-field limit, quantifies the loss in received power due to this phenomenon in the two-ray model. To prevent this phenomenon, magnesium fluoride is commonly deposited onto materials. Lord Rayleigh discovered that this phenomenon can be reduced by putting a thin film with an intermediate (*) refractive index on top of a material, which causes destructive interference. This phenomenon occurs isotropically in its idealized Lambertian form. The specular form of this phenomenon occurs at an equal angle to the incident angle and can be reduced by A·R coatings. For 10 points, name this phenomenon in which waves return to their original medium after bouncing off objects such as mirrors.
tossups.answer: reflections [accept Lambertian reflections; accept specular reflections; accept anti-reflective coating; accept (ground) reflection coefficient]

tossups.question: This city’s neighborhood of Florentin contains most of the works of Dede (“de-de”), a graffiti artist who prominently displays bandaids in his work. A massive new park in this city is located on top of the 60 meter-tall Hiriya garbage dump. A historic part of this city names the almost-seedless shatoumi orange. This city’s name is a translation of the title of the utopian novel Altneuland. This city contains the “White City,” the world’s largest collection of (*) Bauhaus-style buildings. This most populous city in the Gush Dan metropolitan area includes the ancient port of Jaffa. Donald Trump controversially moved an embassy [emphasize] away from this city in 2018. For 10 points, name this Mediterranean city northwest of Jerusalem, the economic center of Israel.
tossups.answer: Tel Aviv-Yafo [or Tall ʾAbīb-Yāfā, accept Jaffa or Yafo or Yāfā or Jaffa oranges until “Jaffa” is read; reject “Haifa”]

tossups.question: Either the general class of diseases or specific examples are acceptable until read. This class of diseases can manifest in neutrophilic dermatoses such as Sweet’s syndrome or the BADAS (“Bad-ass”) rash. The markers ASCA and ANCA can increase diagnostic accuracy in cases of the “indeterminate” form of this disease. The drug vedolizumab is effective against both main subtypes of this class of disease, in contrast to the first-line treatment mesalazine. A type of this disease is characterized by the (*) cobblestone-like appearance of tissue and the presence of “skip” lesions. The two main subtypes of this disease are distinguished by whether lesioning is widespread or localized to the lower ileum. For 10 points, what group of diseases, whose two main types are Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis, is named for the symptom of pain and swelling in the gastrointestinal tract?
tossups.answer: inflammatory bowel disease [or IBD; accept Crohn’s disease or ulcerative colitis or UC or indeterminate colitis or IC before mentioned; prompt on bowel or gastrointestinal or GI disease; prompt on autoimmune disease; reject “irritable bowel syndrome” or “IBS”]

tossups.question: The speaker of a poem addressed to this poet repeats, “They thought you would stop pursuing the white elephant.” The end of Derek Walcott’s poem “Six Fictions” references a poem by this author in which the speaker says, “Now my heart is sore.” Christopher Okigbo’s “Lament of the Masks” celebrates this poet’s centenary. A line by this poet titles a [emphasize] different author’s novel in which a boy cries to his father, “They have killed me!” before being cut down by a machete. This author wrote that certain lines (*) “stirred my blood as nothing has for years” in his preface to Gitanjali. In a novel that takes its title from this poet, a man beats his wife during the Week of Peace in Umuofia (“oo-moo-OH-fee-ah”). For 10 points, a Chinua Achebe novel takes its title from what author’s line “Things fall apart” in his poem “The Second Coming”?
tossups.answer: W. B. Yeats [or William Butler Yeats]

tossups.question: In a decision overturning a KKK-supported law involving these people, Justice McReynolds held that this sort of person is “not the mere creature of the state.” Bailey v. Drexel Furniture struck down a tax named for these people, who are definitionally the only people who can commit “status offenses.” These people’s rights as criminal defendants were recognized in Roper v. Simmons. The Hague Maintenance Convention concerns a type of periodic (*) payment named for this sort of person that courts can order from an “obligor” (“ob-lig-OR”). A law banning the trade of items made by these people was struck down in Hammer v. Dagenhart. Topics in the area of law concerning these people include emancipation and delinquency. For 10 points, name this sort of person who is under the age of majority.
tossups.answer: children [or minors; or juveniles; or underage people; accept child laborers; accept kids but prompt on other synonyms or colloquialisms like youth]

tossups.question: People with this occupation were forbidden from riding on horseback during the reign of Emperor Gāozǔ (“gow-dzoo”) of Hàn. A prominent group of people with this occupation from Shānxī (“shahn-shee”) founded institutions called piàohào (“pyow-how”), while Huīzhōu's (“hway-joh’s”) group of them was often praised for their morality. Members of this occupation were required to pay for vouchers by a policy change by Emperor Wǔ​​ (“oo”) of Hàn that was the subject of a later debate between “reformists” and “modernists,” the (*) Discourses on Salt and Iron. Under the cohong system, members of this occupation operated out of the Thirteen Factories at Canton. This occupation was placed at the bottom of the Confucian hierarchy of occupations, below literati, farmers, and artisans. For 10 points, caravanserais often housed members of what occupation as they engaged in commerce on the Silk Road?
tossups.answer: merchants [accept traders or bankers, or shāng, accept Shānxī merchants or Jin merchants or Jìnshāng; accept Huī merchants or Huīshāng]

tossups.question: A Melissa Solomon essay about this novel examines the lesbian interests of a character who accuses her ex-lover of having “dried up [her] soul” and later wonders, “Have I been so vile all for nothing?” The protagonist of this novel sees a dead relative next to her bed after he had earlier told her she could not see the ghost of the manor without suffering. The protagonist of this novel helps a woman marry the art collector Edward Rosier against the wishes of her father. In this novel, (*) Countess Gemini exposes Madame Merle’s affair with the protagonist’s husband. This novel’s protagonist goes to a convent to visit her stepdaughter and rejects her suitors Lord Warburton and Caspar Goodwood to marry Gilbert Osmond. For 10 points, name this novel about Isabel Archer, written by Henry James.
tossups.answer: The Portrait of a Lady (The essay is “The Female World of Exorcism and Displacement (Or, Relations between Women in Henry James’s Nineteenth-Century The Portrait of a Lady).”)

tossups.question: A holder of this office received a dispatch from Charles Wood suggesting that local colleges teach in English. A holder of this office was nicknamed “Clemency” after issuing an amnesty proclamation. As part of his namesake “code,” a holder of this office enacted a system of fixed land revenues called the “Permanent Settlement.” A former holder of this office, known for dueling Philip Francis, faced an unsuccessful (*) seven-year impeachment trial. Holders of this office extended their territory when local rulers died without natural heirs under the “Doctrine of Lapse.” This office was held by Warren Hastings and Lord Mountbatten. For 10 points, a holder of what office launched overseas service that triggered the “Sepoy Rebellion” as the local head of British India?
tossups.answer: Governor-General of India [or Viceroy of India; accept Governor-General of Bengal; accept Governor-General of the Presidency of Fort William; accept Secretary of State for India; accept the British Raj in place of “India”; prompt on Governor-General or Viceroy until “India”; prompt on governor of India; prompt on leader of India; prompt on ruler of India]

tossups.question: After creating Atlantic City’s “Lucy,” James V. Lafferty built this neighborhood’s zoomorphic concert hall and brothel, the Elephantine Colossus. It's not in Chicago, but a section of this neighborhood nicknamed “Streets of Cairo” was home to three “Little Egypt” “hoochie coochie” belly dancers. A Polish doctor with a similar name to this neighborhood displayed premature babies in (*) incubators at his “Infantorium” here before the 1911 Dreamland Fire. This area’s name might derive from a Dutch word for “rabbit.” Tourists traversed this neighborhood’s Riegelmann Boardwalk to visit the wooden Cyclone and Wonder Wheel. This neighborhood was dubbed the “nickel empire” for the cost of subway fare, rides, and Nathan’s Famous hot dogs. For 10 points, name this early amusement resort in Brooklyn.
tossups.answer: Coney Island [accept Luna Park or Steeplechase Park; accept Dreamland until read; accept Brighton Beach; accept Gravesend; prompt on Brooklyn or NYC or New York City] (The doctor was Martin A. Couney. The Dutch word is konijn.)

tossups.question: Excesses of this element in pillow basalts are highest in the glassy exterior and correlate to the depth of the overlying ocean. Abundance of this light element is measured via heating as its closure temperature is incredibly low owing to a consistent failure to be integrated into minerals. This element is generated in place by neutron irradiation to allow use of a single sample in the enhancement of a technique commonly applied to orthoclase (*) feldspar endmembers. This element’s ratio with potassium-40 is used in radioactive dating of sedimentary rocks, which rarely retain it. This element has higher atmospheric concentration than water vapor or carbon dioxide. For 10 points, name this third-most common gas in air, the most common and third-heaviest noble gas.
tossups.answer: argon [or Ar; prompt on potassium-argon or K-Ar dating until “potassium” and accept afterwards]

tossups.question: At the end of a play, an instance of this action prompts two men to argue whether “sorrow set free what is noble” in an inventor. An ex-clergyman claims “we can never escape [the White Horses]” before performing this action with his partner. In another play, the audience realizes that a girl did this action after her grandfather emerges; that girl performs this action after her father calls her an “interloper.” In another play, a man cries, (*) “Good God!—people don’t do such things” in response to a woman doing this action after she plays “wild dance music” on the piano. Judge Brack causes the title character to perform this action after learning she convinced Eilert Løvborg to do it. For 10 points, in The Wild Duck, Hedvig performs what action that Hedda Gabler does with her father’s pistol?
tossups.answer: committing suicide [accept equivalents such as killing oneself; accept shooting oneself or similar; prompt on death or jumping into a water wheel or jumping into a mill race]

tossups.question: The sight of a dozen swans indicate this city is safe to approach, according to a poorly disguised goddess who interrupts a lament mid-sentence. Agod bristling at a transgression into his territory allows a group to approach this city in another use of aposiopesis. This city houses a well-kept shrine to Sychaeus, as well as pictures of an event six years ago that drive a man to tears. In an extended metaphor, the hustle and bustle of this (*) growing city is compared to bees in their hive. A man tells the story of the Trojan Horse while staying at this favorite city of Juno. This city’s leader falls on a sword atop a pyre fueled by the arms of the departing son of Venus. For 10 points, name this North African city where Aeneas fell in love with Dido, foreshadowing its war with Rome.
tossups.answer: Carthage [or Carthago]

tossups.question: This piece begins with the orchestra playing the fortissimo fanfare “B-flat, B-flat, up to long F, [pause] triplet B-flats, long F,” introducing this piece’s recurring duplet-triplet rhythmic motif. Performances of this piece, which inspired Pyotr Tchaikovsky to compose his violin concerto, frequently omit its third movement intermezzo to fit the four-movement structure implied by its title. This piece’s second movement is based on a (*) seguidilla and opens with a habanera. Though the subsequently composed opera Le roi d’Ys was more famous in its composer’s native France, this piece became its composer’s best-known work, sparking a wave of interest in Iberian music. For 10 points, name this piece written for Pablo Sarasate by Édouard Lalo that, despite its name, is a violin concerto.
tossups.answer: Symphonie espagnole in D minor [or Spanish Symphony; accept Édouard Lalo’s Opus 21]

tossups.question: A member of this movement worked out 66 classes based on concepts like the “dynamic object” in collaboration with Victoria, Lady Welby. The “critical common-sensism” of a member of this movement has been used to chart a course between “deferentialism” and “cynicism” about science by a proponent of this movement, Susan Haack. The concepts of a “community of inquiry” and “abductive reasoning” were introduced by a (*) logician from this movement who developed a triadic approach to semiotics. Cheryl Misak’s history of this philosophical school of thought includes Jane Addams, who influenced the author of Democracy and Education. Truth as “cash-value” is a main idea of, for 10 points, what school of thought of John Dewey, Charles Sanders Peirce, and William James?
tossups.answer: pragmatism [or pragmaticism; or pragmatists or pragmatic philosophy; prompt on semiotics or significs by asking “as part of what more general philosophical movement?”; reject “pragmatics”]

tossups.question: This material mirrors “queer and trans survival and thriving” according to the artist of a work that depicts a van inspired by the Van Dykes, L.J. Roberts. Pieces of this non-latex material are used in Contingent by Eva Hesse. Traditional forms of this material inspired a bottle-cap version used in many works by El Anatsui. This material is used to depict a girl flying over the George Washington Bridge in Tar Beach 2. A 24.5-mile-long work made of this material in California used steel cables to support its (*) panels. Running Fence is a large-scale work using this material by Christo and Jeanne-Claude, who also used this material to wrap the Reichstag. For 10 points, what material was used by Faith Ringgold to make quilts?
tossups.answer: fabric [accept textiles; accept any specific types of fabric, like nylon, cotton, yarn, or cloth; accept kente cloth; accept cheesecloth; prompt on quilts by asking “made of what general material?”]

tossups.question: Tetra-alkylated ammonium salts can recognize species with this property in solution and may replace Cinchona alkaloids for that purpose. List and MacMillan split half of the 2021 Nobel for their work in producing this property using small organic molecules. sp2-hybridized groups can generate this property from either their (*) re (“ray”) or si (“sai”) face. Covalently bonding a bulky auxiliary onto a reactant can generate a form of this property by biasing a reaction. Amines struggle to retain this property because of the nitrogen inversion. This property can be quantified using the ee, which measures the excess of light polarized in a given direction. For 10 points, name this property of molecules that cannot be superimposed on their mirror image.
tossups.answer: chirality [or pseudo-enantiomerism; accept enantioselectivity or enantiomeric excess; accept chiral auxiliaries; prompt on asymmetry or selectivity]

tossups.question: The commander Euphemius rebelled in this region after he refused to end his forced marriage to a nun. The Byzantine Emperor Constans II moved the capital to this region after fleeing here to escape popular anger over the murder of his brother. The siege of Panormus was won in this region by Belisarius during the Gothic War. This was the southernmost region conquered by two brothers from the (*) Hauteville dynasty, including one nicknamed “Bosso” and the eventual victor at the 1081 Battle of Dyrrhachium. A 13th-century Eastertide revolt against French rule of this region was its namesake “Vespers.” For 10 points, King Roger II ruled over a population including Arabs and Normans on what island, which is adjacent to the strategic Straits of Messina?
tossups.answer: Sicily [or Sicilia, Ṣiqilliya, Sicile, or Sikelia; accept Sicilian Vespers or Vespri siciliani]

tossups.question: In a parody of this novel, the protagonist meets a giant whose gaze makes things transparent and a female knight who leads him to the Grand Canyon during his search for a faraway island. At the end of a story that parodies this novel, the narrator awakens from a dream that his companion on a railroad refused to join him on a steamboat and revealed himself as the devil. The narrator frequently compares himself to this novel’s protagonist in The Enormous Room. The (*) March sisters act out passages from this novel in the first chapter of Little Women. A judge sentences the protagonist’s companion Faithful to death in this novel, whose locations include Vanity Fair and the Slough of Despond. For 10 points, name this allegorical novel titled for Christian’s journey, written by John Bunyan.
tossups.answer: The Pilgrim’s Progress [or The Pilgrim's Progress from This World, to That Which Is to Come] (The first two sentences are from C.S. Lewis’s The Pilgrim’s Regress and Hawthorne’s “The Celestial Railroad.”)

bonuses.leadin: Plays in this language were performed in the “Rialto” theater district on Second Avenue, where leading actresses often took the role nicknamed “Queen Lear,” Mirele Efros. For 10 points each:
answers: Yiddish
Adler [accept Jacob Adler or Stella Adler]
Clifford Odets
parts: Zero Mostel pioneered the role of Tevye the Milkman in a musical based on Sholem Aleichem’s stories in what language?

Jacob Gordin created the role of the “Yiddish King Lear” for an Odessa-born actor from this family. As a part of the Group Theatre, his daughter of this surname brought Stanislavski’s method acting techniques to the US.

Mr. Prince declares himself an “American King Lear” in this author’s play A Rocket to the Moon. Stella Adler premiered the role of Bessie Berger in this author’s play about a Jewish family in the Bronx, Awake and Sing!

bonuses.leadin: The second of these pieces repeatedly quotes the beginning of Bach’s Partita in E major and includes a “Dance of the Shades.” For 10 points each:
answers: Six Sonatas for Solo Violin, Op. 27 [accept Eugène Ysaÿe’s violin sonatas; prompt on violin sonatas]
Dies irae
César Franck [or César-Auguste Jean-Guillaume Hubert Franck]
parts: Name this collection of six pieces, each of which is dedicated to one of the composer’s contemporary performers. The third of these pieces, nicknamed “Ballade,” is in a single movement and makes heavy use of double and triple stops.

Along with Bach’s Partita in E major, the prelude of the second solo sonata quotes this motif derived from Latin plainchant that often symbolizes death. This motif’s name literally translates to “day of wrath.”
This other Belgian composer wrote his Violin Sonata in A major as a gift for Eugène Ysaÿe’s (“ee-zah-EE’s”) wedding. That violin sonata by this composer is notable for its cyclic form.

bonuses.leadin: In a 1772 riot named for these objects, a New Hampshire mob lashed Sheriff Whiting for trying to enforce the British crown’s claim on all of them large enough to be marked with the king’s “broad arrow.” For 10 points each:
answers: pine trees [accept white pines or Pinus strobus; accept Baltic pines or Scots pines or Pinus sylvestris; accept Pine Tree Flag; accept Pine Tree Riot; accept king pines; prompt on mast trees; prompt on trees or plants; prompt on wood or timber or lumber; reject “fir trees”]
Boston [accept Boston Tea Party]
Navigation Acts [or Acts of Trade and Navigation]
parts: Name these objects that the British Empire imported from New England after the Northern Wars cut off Baltic sources. One of these objects appears below the phrase “An Appeal to Heaven” on a Revolutionary War flag.

Though rarely enforced, the four White Pines Acts infringed on the shipwrights of Connecticut, Portsmouth, and this city. The Pine Tree Riot possibly inspired a 1773 protest led by the Sons of Liberty in this city’s harbor.

Boston became a hub of sugar and molasses smuggling due to later iterations of these mercantilist acts that were strictly enforced by Edmund Andros. These anticompetitive acts restricted colonial trade with foreign powers.

bonuses.leadin: Organisms in this genus can be deactivated by parasitic Lavidaviridae such as the Sputnik virus. For 10 points each:
answers: Mimivirus
citric acid cycle [accept Krebs cycle; accept tricarboxylic acid cycle or TCA cycle]
Eukaryota [accept eukaryotes or eukaryotic cells; accept viral eukaryogenesis hypothesis]
parts: Name this viral genus whose name comes from their discoverer mistaking one of them for a bacterium. Organisms in this genus of giant viruses contain hundreds of often quite complex genes.

In 2020, Moniruzzaman et al. found that some Mimiviruses contain genes encoding for enzymes in this pathway such as succinate dehydrogenase, suggesting that they can “reprogram” their host’s carbon metabolism.

The discovery of giant viruses like mimiviruses strengthened the hypothesis that the first organism in this domain resulted from multiple endosymbioses, which produced a cell containing a nucleus and membrane-bound organelles.

bonuses.leadin: Discussing self-esteem and envy, a book describes a practitioner of this activity in a “mountain village” who thinks he’s skilled until a professional visits. For 10 points each:
answers: playing basketball [or shooting jump shots; prompt on sports or athletics] (Those examples respectively involve Jerry West and Wilt Chamberlain.)
utopia [accept Anarchy, State, and Utopia; prompt on the framework]
exploitation [or word forms like exploiting; accept A General Theory of Exploitation and Class]
parts: Name this activity. In that book, an example in which the distribution D1 becomes D2 when a million people pay a practitioner of this activity 25 cents is used to critique “time-slice” and “end-state” theories of justice.
Robert Nozick used those basketball examples in a book titled for “Anarchy, State” and this sort of ideal society.

Nozick’s discussion of envy leads into an argument against the “Marxian” theory of this concept, which he jokes is aimed at “people’s lack of understanding of economics.” John Roemer’s “general theory” of this phenomenon defines it via “property relations.”

bonuses.leadin: This artist included a steel-blue treasure box and a Byzantine-style gold crown in the foreground of the painting The Rose Bower. For 10 points each:
answers: Edward Burne-Jones [or Edward Coley Burne-Jones]
sleeping [accept Night and Sleep] (The Rose Bower is part of The Legend of Briar Rose, which depicts the Sleeping Beauty legend.)
Annunciation
parts: Name this English painter, an associate of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood who depicted a sorcerer entangled in a hawthorn thicket in The Beguiling of Merlin.

All the figures in The Rose Bower are engaged in this activity. Evelyn De Morgan’s most famous painting depicts a flying personification of this activity, which a woman performs in Frederic Leighton’s Flaming June.

Burne-Jones depicted Mary being visited by a black-robed figure framed by a tall bush in one of these scenes. In Dante Gabriel Rossetti’s depiction of this scene, the lily-bearing angel Gabriel wakes a sleepy Mary from bed.

bonuses.leadin: Kathleen Thelen, a proponent of the “historical” approach to these entities, analyzed how they change through “layering,” “drift,” “conversion,” and “replacement.” For 10 points each:
answers: institutions [accept the New Institutional Economics or historical institutionalism]
revolutions [accept Reflections on the Revolution in France]
cooperation [or word forms; accept The Evolution of Cooperation]
parts: Name these entities. A framework for the “analysis and development” of these entities has been proposed by Elinor Ostrom, whose work applies a “new” school of economics named for these entities to political science.

Theda Skocpol applied “historical institutionalism” in a theory of how state breakdowns allow these events. Edmund Burke wrote some conservative “reflections” on one of these events that began in France in 1789.

Robert Mearsheimer’s critique of institutionalism claims that this behavior is hard to maintain between states due to the threat of “cheating.” This strategy, the alternative to defection, titles Robert Alexrod’s magnum opus.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Gaussian distribution—no, not like that. For 10 points each:
answers: orbitals [accept Gaussian orbitals or atomic orbitals]
John Pople [accept Pople basis sets]
FORTRAN
parts: The hugely influential Gaussian software suite borrows its name from a function approximating these things. The angular momentum quantum number divides atomic examples of these things into s, p, d, and f.

Gaussian has allegedly banned scientists developing competing products, including this Nobel prize winner who helped create the first edition of Gaussian. This scientist’s namesake basis sets use Gaussian orbitals to model the core and valence electrons separately.
Many critics point out that Gaussian is one of countless scientific programs written in this language that remains critical to modern science despite predating BASIC.

bonuses.leadin: President Lucas Mangope tried to suppress unrest in one of these regions, where violence was photographed by the Bang-Bang Club member Greg Marinovich. For 10 points each:
answers: Bantustans [accept Bantu homelands; prompt on reserves; prompt on TBVC States]
Nelson Mandela [or (Nelson) Rolihlahla Mandela or Madiba Mandela]
grand AND petty apartheid
parts: Name these administrative regions, the first of which was organized for the Xhosa (“KAW-sah”) people in Transkei. Self-governance in these regions was promoted by Hendrik Verwoerd’s (“fur-VOORT’s”) “separate development” policy.

This leader of the ANC criticized comparisons between Bantustans and the partition of India, since the latter still maintained equal rights for Hindus and Muslims. This first Black president of South Africa died in 2013.
Two

bonuses.leadin: Arthur Machen (“MACK-en”) claimed that this writer “had nothing of depth in his talk. He glided fantastically, whimsically, over the surface of things.” For 10 points each:
answers: Oscar Wilde [or Oscar Fingal O’Flahertie Wills Wilde]
Pan [accept The Great God Pan]
Decadence [or Decadent movement; or décadentisme or décadisme]
parts: Name this Irish author who created a protagonist who dies after stabbing the title object in The Picture of Dorian Gray.

Wilde supported an Arthur Machen (“MACK-en”) novella named for this god, despite the scandal upon its publication. This god removes Mole’s and Rat’s memories of their meeting with him in The Wind in the Willows.

The Great God Pan and numerous works by Wilde are often grouped within this movement, whose British participants were associated with The Yellow Book. Jean Moréas disassociated the Symbolists from this non-Gothic movement themed around aestheticism and experimental hedonism.

bonuses.leadin: A type of fMRI study design described by this term allows for characterization of the hemodynamic response over time due to different stimuli. For 10 points each:
answers: event-related designs [or event-related potentials; accept more specific answers, like rapid event-related; accept erfMRI; accept rapid erfMRI; prompt on evoked potentials or induced potentials by asking “that is a subtype of what kind of potential?”]
priming [or being primed; accept specific types of priming]
attention [accept selective attention]
parts: Give this term that describes an fMRI study design contrasted with block design. This compound adjective also describes potentials measured by EEG, such as P300 and P600.

Both rapid event-related fMRI and event-related potentials can be useful for studying this phenomenon, which occurs when earlier stimulus presentations affect how an individual responds to later stimuli.

In event-related designs, one can randomize stimulus timings to help subjects maintain this state. You might exhibit a “selective” form of this state if you fail to notice a man in a gorilla suit while counting basketball passes.

bonuses.leadin: MIT professor Erik Demaine showed that winning Tetris is in this class. For 10 points each:
answers: NP-complete [accept, BUT DO NOT OTHERWISE REVEAL, nondeterministic polynomial time complete; reject “polynomial time”, “P”, “nondeterministic polynomial time”, “NP”, or “NP-hard”]
polynomial time
planarity [accept planar 3-SAT]
parts: Name this complexity class. Problems in this specific class are the hardest whose solutions can also be verified quickly and include Karp problems like 3-partition.
The time required to reduce Tetris to 3-partition is described by this word and is hence “fast.” The “P” in NP-complete stands for this word, which describes functions like quadratics and cubics.

Demaine’s proof that Super Mario is NP-hard relied on a reduction from 3SAT with this property. The crux of Lichtenstein’s proof that 3SAT with this property is hard was a complicated gadget that replaced crossovers.

bonuses.leadin: A murderer with this profession is identified using the “courtesan method” of examining horse nostrils. For 10 points each:
answers: miniaturist [accept illuminator; prompt on artist or illustrator or artisan or painter]
Orhan Pamuk [or Ferit Orhan Pamuk]
using a plume needle to blind himself [accept any answers involving putting a (turban) needle into his own eyes; prompt on blinding himself by asking “using what?”]
parts: Name this profession of three characters nicknamed Olive, Stork, and Butterfly, who study under Master Osman and work on a secret project commissioned by the Sultan.
The miniaturist Elegant Effendi is murdered for threatening to expose the Sultan’s secret illuminated manuscript in My Name Is Red, a novel by this Turkish author who wrote about the poet Ka in Snow.

The legendary miniaturist Bihzad was said to have taken this specific action to avoid being forced to adopt a new painting style, inspiring Osman to also take this action while examining books in the Sultan’s Treasury.

bonuses.leadin: Alfred V. Kidder identified Verapaz as a site of trade between these two broad areas, which included a zone that was dominated by the early hydraulic state of Kaminaljuyú (“ka-mee-nal-HOO-yoo”) during the Late Preclassic period. For 10 points each:
answers: Highlands AND Lowlands [accept área meridional in place of “Highlands”; accept Northern Lowlands, área septentrional, Southern Lowlands, or área central in place of “Lowlands”]
bloodletting [or blood sacrifice or shedding blood or similar answers like bleeding]
divination [or predicting the future or fortune-telling or similar; accept sortition or casting lots; accept molybdomancy or favomancy or astragalomancy]
parts: Give these two geographic terms that delimit the two centers of Maya civilization. One of these two zones is divided into a northern area that includes Cobá and Izamal and southern sites like Seibal and Uaxactun (“wah-shahk-TOON”) in Petén.

The tombs at Kaminaljuyú suggest that the Highland Maya used stingray spines for this practice, which Lady Xoc (“shoke”) performs in lintels from Yaxchilán (“yahsh-chee-LAHN”). Themison of Laodicea pioneered leeches for this ancient medical practice.

Diego de Landa was horrified by group genital bloodletting rituals like those depicted in the Madrid Codex, which mainly instructed this activity that many cultures performed with beans, knucklebones, or molten metal.

bonuses.leadin: This city is warned, “All your fortresses are like fig trees” in a prophecy by a minor prophet. For 10 points each:
answers: Nineveh [or Naynawa or Ninwe or Ninua or Ninive]
Jonah [or variants like Yōnā, Iōnâs, Yūnus, or Yūnān]
worms [accept maggots or tola’athim]
parts: Name this city that is rebuked in the Book of Nahum. God says, “Should I not have concern for” this city, which contains many animals and over 120,000 people who “cannot tell their right hand from their left.”

This prophet is sent to Nineveh to “preach against it, because its wickedness has come up before me.” In trying to avoid going to Nineveh, this prophet is thrown overboard from a ship and swallowed by a fish.

East of Nineveh, Jonah is shaded by a plant, which is then destroyed by this kind of animal. In Acts Chapter 12 of the Christian Bible, Herod’s failure to give glory to God after a speech led to him being eaten by these animals.

bonuses.leadin: When deriving distribution functions, the existence of this property simplifies calculations by creating groupings within summations and product sequences. For 10 points each:
answers: weak degeneracy [or word forms; accept degenerate perturbation theory or degeneracy parameter]
indistinguishable [or word forms; accept identical particles; accept indiscernible particles]
Satyendra Nath Bose [accept Bose–Einstein distribution; accept bosons]
parts: Name this property whose weak form occurs in a Fermi gas when its namesake parameter is between 1 and 10. Another form of this property can be dealt with by re-diagonalizing a subspace of a system’s Hamiltonian.
Systems of particles with this property have lower degeneracy numbers, since, by the definition of this property, the system remains the same when particles with this property are permuted.
This Indian physicist co-names a distribution with Einstein for indistinguishable particles that can share quantum states and also names the corresponding integer-spin particles.

bonuses.leadin: A poet tells this man that he will “speak true things” at the end of a proem addressed to the Muses. For 10 points each:
answers: Perses [prompt on Hesiod’s brother]
Works and Days [or Erga kai Hemerai]
Pandora
parts: Name this native of Ascra, the addressee of a didactic poem instructing him on agriculture. Early in the poem, he is accused of stealing part of his brother’s inheritance and bribing the “gift-devouring” kings to accept his claim.

Perses is the addressee of this poem, which doubles as a guide to living an honest life. This poem by Hesiod introduces the motif of the five “Ages of Man” and contains the fable of the hawk and the nightingale.
Works and Days tells the story of this first human woman, who scattered “evils and heavy toil and painful diseases” by opening a jar given by Zeus.

bonuses.leadin: In 1856, a trove of golden crosses and these objects was uncovered at Guarrazar, including one ringed by gold hanging letters that spell out “Recceswinth offers this.” For 10 points each:
answers: crowns [accept Iron Crown of Lombardy or Corona Ferrea]
Visigoths [or Visigothi or visigodos; accept Visigothic Spain; prompt on Goths]
Arianism [or Arian heresy]
parts: Name these objects gifted as votive offerings in the early medieval period. The small size of another of these objects supposedly crafted around a nail from the Crucifixion suggests it was also intended as a votive offering.
The twenty-six gold crowns and crosses that make up the Treasure of Guarrazar were created by this Germanic people, who sacked Rome in 410 CE under Alaric and later established a kingdom in Iberia.

King Recceswinth offered the crowns to the Pope as a display of submission after the Visigoths converted to Catholicism from this heretical doctrine, which held that the Son was created by, and is subordinate to, the Father.

bonuses.leadin: Creepy stop motion-animated creatures made of animal bones appear in a film adaptation of Alice in Wonderland from this country. For 10 points each:
answers: Czechoslovakia [or Czechia or the Czech Republic or Česká republika; or Československo; accept Czechoslovak New Wave or Czech New Wave] (Alice was directed by Jan Švankmajer; Daisies was directed by Věra Chytilová)
Jacques Rivette
David Lynch [or David Keith Lynch]
parts: Name this country where a film about girls called Marie I and Marie II, Daisies, was shot during its “New Wave.” The director of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest and Amadeus, Miloš Forman, was from this country.

This French director referenced Alice in Wonderland with a scene in which one of the title women follows the other around Paris, attempting to return items that the latter has dropped, in his film Céline and Julie Go Boating.

Theories often connect Alice in Wonderland to the work of this American director, who included the fake sitcom Rabbits in the film Lost Empire and mentioned a “cottontail rabbit” in the first episode of Twin Peaks.

bonuses.leadin: The sun on this country’s flag contains 40 rays to represent the 40 tribes that Manas supposedly united against the Mongols. For 10 points each:
answers: Kyrgyzstan [or Kyrgyz Republic or Kyrgyz Respublikasy or Kyrgyzskaya Respublika]
Lake Issyk-Kul [or Ysyk-Köl]
Tiān Shān [accept Tengir-Too; prompt on translations like Heavenly Mountains]
parts: Name this former Soviet republic in Central Asia that has its capital at Bishkek.
This large endorheic lake in Kyrgyzstan has a name meaning “hot lake,” since it does not freeze over winter. The region around this lake has been speculated as the point of origin of the Black Death.
The Kungey Alatau of this mountain range runs along the northern shore of Issyk-Kul. Tulips originated in this mountain range, whose lowest point is in the Turpan Depression in Xīnjiāng​​.
